message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PKD1 mutations are associated with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, which typically presents with bilateral kidney enlargement that can be seen on ultrasound. Cysts may not be visible shortly after birth, and adrenal atrophy is not typically associated with this condition. Therefore, the most likely answer is (A) bilateral kidney enlargement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PKD1 is the gene that, when mutated, causes autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). ADPKD typically presents with bilateral kidney enlargement due to the formation of multiple cysts. However, these cysts may not be visible on ultrasound immediately after birth, so the correct answer is "normal kidneys."

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PKD1 mutation leads to polycystic kidney disease, which causes bilateral kidney enlargement. However, this usually presents later in life and may not be detectable by ultrasound shortly after birth. Therefore, the correct answer is normal kidneys.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PKD1 (polycystic kidney disease 1) is an inherited condition that causes the formation of fluid-filled cysts in the kidneys. However, these cysts typically develop slowly and are not visible on an ultrasound shortly after birth. Therefore, the most likely finding would be normal kidneys. Bilateral kidney enlargement and microscopic cysts would be seen later in life as the disease progresses. Adrenal atrophy is not associated with PKD1.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PKD1 mutation causes autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, which leads to the development of multiple cysts in the kidneys over time. However, these cysts are not typically present at birth and would not be visible on an abdominal ultrasound shortly after birth. Therefore, the most likely finding on an abdominal ultrasound would be normal kidneys.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PKD1 on chromosome 16 encodes for polycystin-1, which plays a crucial role in renal tubular development and maintenance. Mutations in this gene can lead to autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), which is characterized by multiple fluid-filled cysts in the kidneys. However, these cysts typically do not develop until later in life, and an ultrasound shortly after birth would not reveal them. Therefore, the correct answer is (D), normal kidneys.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A mutation in the PKD1 gene is associated with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). However, cysts usually do not form until later in life, so an abdominal ultrasound shortly after birth would reveal normal kidneys. Bilateral kidney enlargement will eventually occur, but not immediately after birth. Adrenal atrophy is not directly related to PKD1 mutations.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PKD1 mutation is associated with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. However, kidney cysts typically do not form until adolescence or later. Therefore, an ultrasound shortly after birth would most likely show normal kidneys.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PKD1 is a gene responsible for autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. However, cysts do not usually appear on ultrasound until adulthood, so a newborn ultrasound would most likely reveal normal kidneys. Adrenal atrophy is not associated with PKD1.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PKD1 is associated with polycystic kidney disease, which leads to the formation of fluid-filled cysts in the kidneys. However, these cysts typically do not develop until later in life, so an abdominal ultrasound shortly after birth would most likely reveal normal kidneys.
